definition: A chronic immune-mediated inflammatory skin disease characterized by well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scale, affecting extensor surfaces and scalp.
clinical: Classic presentation involves well-marginated erythematous plaques with adherent silvery/micaceous scale. Removal of scale reveals bleeding points (Auspitz sign). Common sites include extensor surfaces (elbows, knees), buttocks, scalp, and retroauricular areas. Inverse psoriasis affects flexural areas. Nail involvement includes oil spots, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis. May be associated with psoriatic arthritis.
pathogenesis: Immune-mediated process involving T-cell activation and cytokine cascades (IL-17, IL-23, IL-36). Upregulation of IL-36 is a specific feature.
macroscopic: Erythematous plaques with silvery scale. Variants include rupioid (limpet-like scale), inverse, and volar types.
microscopic: Characterized by 'psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia' (acanthosis with regular elongation of rete ridges, often clubbed or 'holding hands'). Key features include thinning of suprapapillary plates, hypogranulosis, and confluent parakeratosis containing neutrophils (Munro microabscesses). Spongiform pustules of Kogoj are neutrophilic collections in the spinous layer. Dilated, tortuous capillaries are present in the dermal papillae. Eosinophils are typically absent in classic plaque psoriasis.
ancillary_studies: IHC: Interleukin-36 gamma (IL-36) shows strong expression/upregulation in the upper epidermis (highly specific compared to eczema). Beta-defensin 2 is variably positive.
differential_diagnosis: Spongiotic dermatitis (eczema), Dermatophytosis (Tinea), Seborrheic dermatitis, Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP), Mycosis Fungoides, ILVEN.
prognosis_and_prediction: Chronic course with exacerbations and remissions. Association with metabolic syndrome and arthritis.

related_figures.legend: Classic extensor presentation of well-marginated plaques. (Time: 8s)
Adherent silvery/micaceous scale on an erythematous plaque. (Time: 47s)
Diagram highlighting psoriasiform hyperplasia, thin suprapapillary plates, and dilated vessels. (Time: 167s)
Histology showing regular acanthosis, thin suprapapillary plates, and parakeratosis. (Time: 307s)
High power showing Munro microabscesses and spongiform pustules. (Time: 328s)
Comparison of IL-36 staining: Strong expression in Psoriasis vs. minimal in Spongiotic Dermatitis. (Time: 899s)

definition: A severe form of psoriasis involving widespread erythema and scaling affecting the majority of the body surface area.
clinical: Diffuse generalized erythema (erythroderma) with scaling. Represents rapid epidermal turnover. Can be difficult to distinguish clinically from drug eruptions or Sezary syndrome.
pathogenesis: Severe exacerbation of psoriatic inflammation.
microscopic: May not show classic psoriasiform hyperplasia due to rapid turnover. Features include broad but thin areas of parakeratosis and hypogranulosis. Unlike plaque psoriasis, eosinophils may be present, complicating differentiation from drug eruptions.
differential_diagnosis: Drug eruption, Atopic dermatitis (erythrodermic), Sezary syndrome/Mycosis Fungoides.
prognosis_and_prediction: Can be life-threatening due to fluid/protein loss and infection risk.

related_figures.legend: Broad parakeratosis and less distinct hyperplasia in erythrodermic psoriasis. (Time: 549s)
Presence of neutrophils in the setting of erythroderma. (Time: 594s)

definition: An acute eruption of small, drop-like psoriatic papules, often triggered by streptococcal infection.
clinical: Small 'drop-like' (gutta = drop) papules and plaques. Often follows streptococcal pharyngitis. Can exhibit the Koebner phenomenon (linear lesions at sites of trauma).
pathogenesis: Associated with superantigens from streptococcal infection.
microscopic: Early lesions may be subtle, lacking full psoriasiform hyperplasia. Key features include a small mound of parakeratosis with neutrophils, slight spongiosis, and dilated papillary dermal vessels. Later lesions show more developed acanthosis and thinning of suprapapillary plates.
differential_diagnosis: Pityriasis Rosea, Pityriasis Lichenoides (PLEVA), Secondary Syphilis, Dermatophytosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Often self-limited; may progress to chronic plaque psoriasis.

related_figures.legend: Typical drop-like lesions. (Time: 3319s)
Early histologic changes: mild spongiosis and dilated vessels. (Time: 3367s)
Mounds of parakeratosis with neutrophils in a developing lesion. (Time: 3399s)

definition: A broad category of inflammatory skin conditions characterized histologically by intercellular edema (spongiosis). Includes nummular, dyshidrotic, and allergic/irritant contact dermatitis.
clinical: Variable presentation; Acute lesions show vesicles and weeping; Subacute/Chronic lesions show scaling and lichenification. Nummular dermatitis presents as coin-shaped plaques with honey-colored crust.
pathogenesis: T-cell mediated hypersensitivity or barrier dysfunction.
macroscopic: Erythematous papules, vesicles, or plaques. Nummular type is discoid.
microscopic: Essential feature is spongiosis (intercellular edema). Acute lesions show intraepidermal vesicles (spongiotic vesicles). Subacute/Chronic lesions show mild spongiosis, acanthosis, and scale. Eosinophils are commonly present in the infiltrate. Unlike psoriasis, there is no thinning of suprapapillary plates or regular rete ridge elongation.
ancillary_studies: IHC: IL-36 shows minimal/negative expression (useful to distinguish from psoriasis). Beta-defensin 2 is variable.
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, Tinea, Seborrheic dermatitis, Pre-bullous pemphigoid.
staging: Categorized as Acute, Subacute, or Chronic.

related_figures.legend: Vase-like vesicles indicative of acute spongiosis. (Time: 729s)
Presence of eosinophils in the dermal infiltrate. (Time: 767s)
Psoriasiform spongiotic dermatitis lacking neutrophils, distinguishing it from psoriasis. (Time: 772s)

definition: Inflammatory skin changes on the lower extremities secondary to chronic venous insufficiency.
clinical: Erythema, scale, and hyperpigmentation on the lower legs.
pathogenesis: Venous hypertension leading to capillary proliferation and inflammation.
macroscopic: Red-brown scaly plaques on lower legs.
microscopic: Spongiosis accompanied by a lobular proliferation of thick-walled capillaries in the papillary dermis. Extravasated red blood cells and hemosiderin deposition are common. Fibrosis may be present.
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, Nummular dermatitis, Tinea.

related_figures.legend: Lobular vascular proliferation and fibrosis on the lower extremity. (Time: 796s)

definition: Thickening of the skin (lichenification) caused by repetitive rubbing or scratching.
clinical: Elevated plaque with accentuated skin markings (lichenification). Often has a shiny surface.
pathogenesis: Secondary to chronic mechanical trauma (itch-scratch cycle).
microscopic: Characteristic 'Hairy Palm Sign': Resembles acral skin (hypergranulosis, compact hyperkeratosis) but contains hair follicles. Rete ridges are irregularly elongated. Vertical streaking of collagen in papillary dermis (rubbing fibrosis).
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, Chronic eczema, Hypertrophic Lichen Planus.

related_figures.legend: Transition from normal skin to 'hairy palm' changes: hypergranulosis and compact hyperkeratosis. (Time: 1005s)
Marked epidermal hyperplasia with hypergranulosis and hair follicles ('Hairy Palm Sign'). (Time: 1076s)

definition: A chronic condition characterized by intensely pruritic, hyperkeratotic nodules, often described as 'picker's nodules'.
clinical: Multiple firm, excoriated, hyperkeratotic nodules.
pathogenesis: Chronic picking and scratching.
microscopic: Features of Lichen Simplex Chronicus plus pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia (PEH). Thick crust, hemorrhage, and vertical fibrosis are common. Nerve fiber hyperplasia may be present.
differential_diagnosis: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (due to PEH), Keratoacanthoma.

related_figures.legend: Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia with crust and hemorrhage. (Time: 1142s)

definition: A fungal infection of the keratinized tissues (skin, hair, nails) caused by dermatophytes.
clinical: Annular or nummular lesions with a scaly advancing border. May involve scalp (Tinea capitis), body (Tinea corporis), or feet (Tinea pedis).
pathogenesis: Infection by dermatophyte fungi.
microscopic: Spongiosis and neutrophils in the stratum corneum are clues. The 'Sandwich Sign' is classic: layers of orthokeratosis, parakeratosis with neutrophils, and basket-weave orthokeratosis. Hyphae are found in the cornified layer.
ancillary_studies: Stains: PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff) highlights septate hyphae. GMS (Grocott Methenamine Silver) can also be used.
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, Nummular dermatitis, Candidiasis.

related_figures.legend: Spongiosis with neutrophils in the upper epithelium. (Time: 1217s)
Sandwich sign: Alternating layers of cornification where organisms are found. (Time: 1310s)
PAS stain showing septate fungal hyphae. (Time: 1394s)

definition: A fungal infection caused by Candida species, often affecting intertriginous areas.
clinical: Erythema in folds (inguinal, scrotum, inframammary) with satellite pustules.
pathogenesis: Candida yeast infection favored by moisture.
macroscopic: Beefy red plaques with satellite lesions.
microscopic: Subcorneal pustules containing neutrophils. Spongiosis.
ancillary_studies: Stains: PAS highlights budding yeasts and pseudohyphae.
differential_diagnosis: Tinea, Seborrheic dermatitis, Intertrigo.

related_figures.legend: PAS stain showing budding yeast forms in the stratum corneum. (Time: 1451s)

definition: A chronic papulosquamous disorder affecting seborrheic areas (face, scalp, chest).
clinical: Erythema and greasy scale in nasolabial folds, eyebrows, retroauricular areas, scalp (dandruff/cradle cap), and chest/back.
pathogenesis: Reaction to Malassezia yeast in sebum-rich areas.
microscopic: Spongiosis and psoriasiform hyperplasia (less regular than psoriasis). Key feature is 'shoulder parakeratosis'—parakeratosis and spongiosis accentuated at the follicular ostia. Neutrophils often present in scale crust. Plasma cells may be seen.
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis (sebopsoriasis overlap exists), Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (in infants), Tinea.

related_figures.legend: Follicular accentuation of parakeratosis ('shoulder parakeratosis'). (Time: 1532s)
Neutrophils within the follicular parakeratosis. (Time: 1574s)

definition: A chronic papulosquamous disorder characterized by reddish-orange plaques, palmoplantar keratoderma, and follicular papules.
clinical: Cephalocaudal spread of erythema, 'islands of sparing' (normal skin within erythema), follicular hyperkeratosis ('nutmeg grater' feel), and 'carnauba wax' thick yellow palmoplantar keratoderma.
pathogenesis: Unknown.
microscopic: Psoriasiform hyperplasia with *minimal* inflammation. Characteristic 'Checkerboard pattern' of parakeratosis (alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis both vertically and horizontally). Follicular plugging (shoulder parakeratosis). Focal acantholysis may be seen.
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, Seborrheic dermatitis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Variable; classic adult type often remits after 3-5 years.

related_figures.legend: Psoriasiform hyperplasia with minimal inflammation. (Time: 1749s)
Checkerboard pattern of alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis. (Time: 1774s)
Focal suprabasilar acantholysis, a helpful clue in PRP. (Time: 1868s)

definition: A linear, pruritic, psoriasiform eruption following Blaschko's lines, typically appearing in childhood.
clinical: Linear verrucous plaques on extremities following lines of Blaschko. Intense pruritus.
pathogenesis: Mosaicism (somatic mutation).
microscopic: Psoriasiform hyperplasia. Characteristic alternating pattern of cornification: Areas of parakeratosis with hypogranulosis alternating horizontally with areas of orthokeratosis and hypergranulosis (depressed epidermis). Spongiosis may be present.
differential_diagnosis: Linear Psoriasis, Lichen Striatus.

related_figures.legend: Alternating zones of parakeratosis/hypogranulosis and hypergranulosis/orthokeratosis. (Time: 2020s)

definition: Dermatitis caused by deficiencies in zinc, amino acids, or vitamins, showing a characteristic necrolytic pattern.
clinical: Includes Acrodermatitis Enteropathica (Zinc), Necrolytic Migratory Erythema (Glucagonoma), Pellagra (Niacin), Kwashiorkor (Protein). Periorificial and acral erosive dermatitis.
pathogenesis: Nutritional deficiency leads to keratinocyte necrosis.
macroscopic: Erosive, crusted, well-marginated plaques, often periorificial.
microscopic: Sudden pallor/ballooning of the upper epidermis, loss of the granular layer, and necrotic keratinocytes. Confluent parakeratosis. Psoriasiform hyperplasia in chronic lesions.
ancillary_studies: Serum levels of Zinc, Glucagon, or amino acids.
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, Candida, Seborrheic dermatitis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Reversible with correction of deficiency or removal of tumor (glucagonoma).

related_figures.legend: Upper epidermal pallor, vacuolization, and necrotic keratinocytes. (Time: 2382s)
Pallor and necrosis of the upper epidermis with thick parakeratosis. (Time: 2447s)

definition: A self-limiting linear inflammatory dermatosis following Blaschko's lines, usually in children.
clinical: Linear erythematous papules comprising a band, usually on extremities.
pathogenesis: T-cell mediated response to mosaic clones.
microscopic: Combination of psoriasiform, spongiotic, and lichenoid patterns. Key feature is a deep perivascular and *perieccrine* lymphocytic infiltrate. Necrotic keratinocytes may be seen.
differential_diagnosis: ILVEN, Linear Lichen Planus, Blaschkoid Mycosis Fungoides.
prognosis_and_prediction: Self-limiting, resolves in months to years.

related_figures.legend: Psoriasiform and lichenoid changes with a deep perieccrine infiltrate. (Time: 2662s)
Infiltrate coursing along the eccrine duct and coils. (Time: 2668s)

definition: The pre-bullous stage of bullous pemphigoid presenting with urticarial plaques.
clinical: Urticarial plaques, often annular, which may precede or accompany tense bullae.
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal proteins (BP180, BP230).
microscopic: Eosinophilic spongiosis is characteristic. Eosinophils lining the dermo-epidermal junction. Incipient subepidermal vesiculation.
ancillary_studies: Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF): Linear IgG and C3 at the basement membrane zone.
differential_diagnosis: Urticaria, Drug eruption, Arthropod bite reaction.

related_figures.legend: Incipient subepidermal vesiculation with eosinophils. (Time: 2714s)
Eosinophils lining the dermo-epidermal junction (eosinophilic spongiosis). (Time: 2727s)

definition: The most common form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, presenting initially as patches and plaques.
clinical: Patches and plaques, often with a wrinkled ('cigarette paper') surface, favoring sun-protected sites (buttocks, inner thighs).
pathogenesis: Malignant proliferation of skin-homing T-cells.
macroscopic: Salmon-colored to violaceous patches and plaques.
microscopic: Psoriasiform or lichenoid pattern. Lymphocytes aligned along the basal layer (epidermotropism) with little accompanying spongiosis (disproportionate epidermotropism). Pautrier microabscesses (clusters of atypical lymphocytes). Lymphocytes often have hyperchromatic, cerebriform nuclei and perinuclear halos ('tag-along' lymphocytes). CD8+ variant may show diffuse pagetoid spread.
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD3+, CD4+ (usually), CD8- (usually), loss of CD7. TCR gene rearrangement (clonality).
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, Eczema, Parapsoriasis.

related_figures.legend: Lymphocytes lining up along the junctional zone with minimal spongiosis. (Time: 2885s)
Pautrier microabscess: Intraepidermal collection of atypical lymphocytes. (Time: 2922s)
Heavy epidermotropism (pagetoid spread) of atypical lymphocytes. (Time: 2979s)

definition: A chronic capillaritis characterized by petechiae and pigmentation, with a lichenoid histologic pattern (Gougerot-Blum variant).
clinical: Rust-colored or violaceous plaques, typically on the lower legs.
pathogenesis: Lymphocytic inflammation targeting capillaries.
microscopic: Band-like (lichenoid) lymphocytic infiltrate. Extravasated red blood cells. Siderophages (hemosiderin-laden macrophages) typically found deep in the infiltrate.
differential_diagnosis: Mycosis Fungoides, Stasis dermatitis, Drug eruption.

related_figures.legend: Lichenoid infiltrate with hemorrhage. (Time: 3094s)
Perls iron stain showing numerous siderophages. (Time: 3131s)

definition: The systemic dissemination phase of syphilis infection involving the skin and mucous membranes.
clinical: Ham-colored or copper-penny macules and papules, often on palms and soles. Generalized lymphadenopathy.
pathogenesis: Infection with Treponema pallidum.
microscopic: Psoriasiform and lichenoid pattern with slender rete ridges. The infiltrate is superficial and deep, perivascular and periadnexal, containing plasma cells (key feature). Endothelial swelling may be present. Neutrophils in the stratum corneum.
ancillary_studies: IHC: Treponema pallidum immunostain (positive spirochetes). Silver stain (Steiner/Warthin-Starry) historically used.
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, Pityriasis Rosea, Lichen Planus.

related_figures.legend: Psoriasiform and lichenoid pattern with periadnexal infiltrate. (Time: 3225s)
High power showing numerous plasma cells in the infiltrate. (Time: 3245s)
Treponema pallidum immunostain highlighting spirochetes. (Time: 3273s)

definition: An acute, self-limiting papulosquamous eruption, often viral-associated.
clinical: Herald patch (larger initial plaque) followed by smaller oval plaques in a 'Christmas tree' distribution on the trunk. Collarette scale.
pathogenesis: Likely viral (HHV-6/7 reactivation).
macroscopic: Oval salmon-colored plaques with trailing scale.
microscopic: Mild spongiosis, focal mounds of parakeratosis, and extravasated red blood cells in the papillary dermis. Usually lacks neutrophils.
differential_diagnosis: Guttate Psoriasis, Secondary Syphilis, Drug eruption.

related_figures.legend: Spongiosis with lenticular mounds of parakeratosis and hemorrhage. (Time: 3476s)

definition: A spectrum of inflammatory skin conditions ranging from acute (PLEVA) to chronic (PLC).
clinical: Recurrent crops of erythematous papules. PLEVA (Mucha-Habermann) lesions are crusted/ulcerated; PLC lesions are scaly.
pathogenesis: T-cell mediated clonal proliferation (sometimes considered a lymphoproliferative disorder).
macroscopic: Red papules with scale (PLC) or crust/necrosis (PLEVA).
microscopic: Wedge-shaped dermal infiltrate (superficial and deep). Interface dermatitis with necrotic keratinocytes. Confluent parakeratosis often containing neutrophils. Hemorrhage is common. No eosinophils.
ancillary_studies: TCR gene rearrangement may show clonality.
differential_diagnosis: Guttate Psoriasis, Lymphomatoid Papulosis, Arthropod bite.

related_figures.legend: Wedge-shaped infiltrate with interface change and necrosis. (Time: 3547s)
Psoriasiform changes with parakeratosis and neutrophils, mimicking psoriasis. (Time: 3571s)
